subs.text:
@timtriche The trouble is that it works so well in so many domains that you can be fooled into thinking it is universal. That's why it should be a full year course.
(btw for amateurs playing with fun bits of math that don't do well with arithmetic, Mathemathica is excellent </psa>)
subs.rawText:
@timtriche The trouble is that it works so well in so many domains that you can be fooled into thinking it is universal. That's why it should be a full year course.
(btw for amateurs playing with fun bits of math that don't do well with arithmetic, Mathemathica is excellent </psa>)

subs.text: @timtriche Yes! There should be a full semester-long course in probability. Brushing over dice rolls and the Gaussian distribution in a week or two does more harm than good.
subs.rawText: @timtriche Yes! There should be a full semester-long course in probability. Brushing over dice rolls and the Gaussian distribution in a week or two does more harm than good.

subs.text:
@otrasenda_AC @NahanniFinanci1 @nntaleb @GGCanto Not=more (typo).
There are many plausible narratives for why lanes would be good or bad, but this reminds me of some saying in spring 2020 that masks may *increase* infections because of false sense of security. Well, sure, possible but unlikely, so let‚Äôs look at the data.

subs.text: @eliowa Excellent point. Another one is: how does this compare to other viruses? SARS-CoV-1? Endemic coronaviruses? Adeno or rhinoviruses? EBV? There is so much opportunity here to learn about viral effects and prevention in general that we are missing because of hyperfocus on covid.
subs.rawText: @eliowa Excellent point. Another one is: how does this compare to other viruses? SARS-CoV-1? Endemic coronaviruses? Adeno or rhinoviruses? EBV? There is so much opportunity here to learn about viral effects and prevention in general that we are missing because of hyperfocus on covid.

subs.text: @trishankkarthik @EricTopol To be more specific: the claim "reinfections may be more severe" is correct. They *may*. But there is a wide chasm between that statement and claims made in the Forever Plague article, and there is some evidence that refutes those claims that should have been at least mentioned.
subs.rawText: @trishankkarthik @EricTopol To be more specific: the claim "reinfections may be more severe" is correct. They *may*. subs.text: @tmprowell @trishankkarthik Got it! Your tweet was about community levels though, not transmission, which is what got me confused. Apologies for getting that part wrong!!! Still, good practice to have date+source on any graph, for this reason.

subs.text: @trishankkarthik The tweet was posted yesterday but shows a CDC community transmission map from a period when transmission was high (note that there is no source or date on the all-red map). The actual community transmission level (2nd screenshot) is generally low.

subs.text: Incredible how many poorly reasoned articles about covid, such as the one below, list @EricTopol as a source. Behind every bad argument lies a weasel word ambiguous enough not to be flagged as disinformation but explicit enough to trigger bad reasoning. [link]

subs.text: üìö Catching up with John, the busted high-yield trader in Fooled by Randomness. If you are talking about a 10 sigma event you should have thought in alphas, not sigmas. There may be early hints that the data is not Gaussian but people call them outliers and brush them away. [link]
subs.rawText:
üìö Catching up with John, the busted high-yield trader in Fooled by Randomness.

If you are talking about a 10 sigma event you should have thought in alphas, not sigmas. There may be early hints that the data is not Gaussian but people call them outliers and brush them away. https://t.co/9dS3tchf95

subs.text: üìö Fooled by hindsight bias. This one is for anyone who thinks lockdowns and school closures in the spring of 2020 were a mistake. Making ex post ‚Äúpredictions‚Äù is infinitely easier than ex ante, and gives you a false sense of confidence to boot. Dangerous and stupid. [link]

Give a lecture once and you help a few hundred people (if you‚Äôre lucky). Post the lecture to YouTube and you help millions. 7 years later, I am yet to find a better guide to academic writing. NB: it‚Äôs good to have a live audience. [link]
